label: azimuth
definition: The angle, measured in the horizontal plane, between north (unspecified) and the projection of the borehole axis at the point of measurement. For curved trajectories, the azimuth is measured from the projection of the tangent to the borehole axis at the point of measurement.

label: grid azimuth
definition: The azimuth measured clockwise from the central meridian of a plane-rectangular coordinate system such as a local reference grid.

label: magnetic azimuth
definition: The azimuth measured clockwise from magnetic north through to 360°. This parameter changes with time and thus needs to be qualified by a date.

label: true azimuth
definition: The azimuth measured clockwise from true north (also called geodetic north or geographic north) through 360°.

label: borehole diameter
definition: The width of the borehole.

label: dip
definition: Measured on a vertical plane, dip is the angle of a borehole defined by a tangent line at the point of measurement and the horizontal plane. In the minerals industry, vertical is commonly denoted as –90° and changes to 0° (horizontal). The sum of inclination and dip is 90°.

label: downhole directional survey
definition: A geometric measurement of inclination and azimuth at a certain depth along the borehole trajectory.
altLabels: alignment survey|borehole survey|deviation survey|directional survey|downhole deviation survey|well survey

label: vertical section
definition: The vertical section is the horizontal distance along the centreline of a wellbore to a certain point on a well trajectory, measured along a pre-defined azimuth in the horizontal plane.

label: dogleg rate
definition: A particularly crooked place in a borehole where the trajectory of the borehole in 3D space changes rapidly, either intentionally or unintentionally. In surveying borehole trajectories, a standard calculation of dogleg severity is made, usually expressed in 2D degrees per 30 metres of wellbore length.

label: end point location
definition: The spatial location where the drilling of a borehole was completed, expressed as coordinates and elevation (i.e. x, y, z).
altLabels: EOH|bottom hole location|end of hole|end point

label: inclination
definition: Measured on a vertical plane, inclination is the angle defined by a tangent line to the borehole and a vertical line representing the Earth's gravity vector at the point of measurement. In the energy industry, inclination is usually expressed as an angle from the vertical (0°, downward pointing) to 90° (horizontal). The sum of inclination and dip is 90°. In the resources industry, inclination is often used interchangeably with dip, though the two concepts are not the same.

label: kick-off point
definition: The point at a given measured depth at which a directional borehole is intentionally deviated.

label: magnetic declination
definition: The angle, measured in the horizontal plane, between magnetic north and true north. This angle varies depending on the position on the Earth's surface, and changes over time. By convention, magnetic declination is positive when magnetic north is east of true north, and negative when it is to the west. Magnetic declination is a critical parameter to report in conjunction with magnetic azimuth to fully characterize the 3D orientation of a borehole.

label: start point location
definition: The spatial location where the drilling of a borehole commenced, expressed as coordinates and elevation (i.e. x, y, z).
altLabels: collar|point of origin|start point|top hole location

label: total depth
definition: Total depth is the distance measured along the actual trajectory of the borehole from the borehole start point / surface reference point to the end of the hole where the drilling has stopped.
altLabels: EOH depth|End of hole depth|TD|TML|Total measured length|borehole depth|drillhole depth

label: measured depth from kelly bushing
definition: Measured depth of the borehole measured from the kelly bushing to the point of interest or survey point.

label: measured depth from rotary table
definition: Measured depth of the borehole measured from the rotary table to the point of interest or survey point.

label: measured depth
definition: Measured depth (MD), or drilled to depth (DD), is the distance measured along the actual trajectory of the borehole from the borehole start point / surface reference point to the point of interest or survey point, i.e. to any feature in the hole such as a casing point, a sidewall core or a significant geological marker.

label: pre-collar depth
definition: The measured depth where the pre-collar hole ends and the diamond tail (i.e. diamond drilling) starts, and from which the length/depth of the diamond core is referenced.

label: reduced level depth
definition: Reduced level depth (usually reported as mRL, i.e. metres from reduced level) is the vertical distance between a survey point and the adopted datum plane, i.e. the base elevation that is used as reference to report heights or depths during drilling. The reference datum may be a real or arbitrary location/plane, and is commonly assigned a nominated elevation.

label: true vertical depth
definition: True vertical depth (TVD) of a point within a borehole is the distance of that point from the depth reference level / borehole start point (e.g. mean sea level, kelly bushing, rotary table, ground level, drill collar) projected on a vertical line (i.e. a line connecting the point to the centre of the Earth). This is a calculated or derived depth. In the energy industry, this depth is always calculated from the deviation survey data.

label: true vertical depth below mudline
definition: True vertical depth below mudline (TVDBML) of a point within a borehole is the distance of that point from the mudline projected on a vertical line (i.e. a line connecting the point to the centre of the Earth).

label: true vertical depth drillfloor
definition: True vertical depth drill floor (TVDDF) of a point within a borehole is the distance of that point from the drill floor projected on a vertical line (i.e. a line connecting the point to the centre of the Earth).

label: true vertical depth kelly bushing
definition: True vertical depth kelly bushing (TVDKB) of a point within a borehole is the distance of that point from the kelly bushing projected on a vertical line (i.e. a line connecting the point to the centre of the Earth).

label: true vertical depth rotary table
definition: True vertical depth rotary table (TVDRT) of a point within a borehole is the distance of that point from the rotary table projected on a vertical line (i.e. a line connecting the point to the centre of the Earth).

label: true vertical depth subsea
definition: The true vertical depth subsea (TVDSS) is the vertical distance from the mean sea level to a point on the borehole course. This depth is always calculated from the deviation survey data.
